instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.U4900: What is U4900? This is the System Management Controller(SMC) in older(pre-2013) macbooks.

threads.title: ANOTHER <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> trackpad issue
threads.message:
Hey guys.

this one is fully working system but the trackpad fails - i tried a good working trackpad & keyboard it worked. After few restarts and sitting around for a bit NO trackpad again! It doesnt seem to have any corrosion oh water damage.

im not sure what the best way to diagnose these issues.

I have taken some voltages from around trackpad connector.

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4_TPAD_F</SIGNAL> 5.19v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> 3.33v
<SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> 3.3v
<SIGNAL>SMC_PME_S4_WAKE_L</SIGNAL> 3.297v
<SIGNAL>TPAD_SPI_IF_EN_CONN</SIGNAL> 3.33v

Where is good place to start looking?

threads.title: ANOTHER <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> trackpad issue
threads.message:
Check if trackpad/keyboard always work on boot menu.
I suppose you have an issue once logged into OSX.

Inspect trackpad connector.
Keyboard still working, only trackpad issue?

threads.title: ANOTHER <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> trackpad issue
threads.message:
yes i check once logged into osx. Actually no [B]keyboard [/B]AND no trackpad
i cant get into boot menu when i hold option? maybe coz keyboard also not working

threads.title: ANOTHER <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> trackpad issue
threads.message: I assume you tried known good trackpad flex not just Tpad itself?

threads.title: ANOTHER <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> trackpad issue
threads.message: yep i got a good working shell so i just transplant the logicboard to eliminate keyboard/trackpad issue.

threads.title: ANOTHER <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> trackpad issue
threads.message:
Didn't check <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S4_TPAD_FUSE</SIGNAL>?
Is F4800 OK?

Check <CHIP>U4910</CHIP> area too.

threads.title: ANOTHER <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> trackpad issue
threads.message: <CHIP>U4900</CHIP> area look good. i tested resistors values around seem good. voltage 3.3 on 1, 5, 8
